ground_truth: She seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go, and she nervously looks at a couple of men passersby. He quickly raises his long-focus camera to his eye, and we are now given a waist-high shot as the focus is adjusted by Jeff. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. Getting no reaction, she crosses the street and seats herself at an empty table in front of the cafe, where she orders a drink. She is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a man who enters the picture from the left side. It is Thorwald, carrying a lightweight cardboard box under his arm. The camera pans him over to the right until he is lost behind the building. He is much nearer the lens because he is on this side of the street, and he is, therefore, slightly out of focus. He lowers the lens, and we see Jeff's eyes travel across the screen as he imagines Thorwald's progression. Then sharpening his look, he picks up the long-focus lens, and easing himself back cautiously, begins watching Thorwald. Thorwald comes up the corridor and stands unlocking his door. As he hesitates, we can see the cardboard box he is carrying has the name of a laundry on it. He enters the apartment and turns on the living room lights. He proceeds to the bedroom, and the lights go on there. A number of suits and top coats are lying in an orderly pile on the bed. He takes the laundry out of the box and puts it on the bed next to the suits. Then he goes to the dresser, and instead of putting the laundry away, he proceeds to take out the contents of the drawers--pajamas, shirts, socks, etc. He piles these on the bed. Jeff lowers the camera quickly. He picks up the phone and dials a number, still keeping his eyes on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on filter, then is picked up and answered by a woman. For a moment, Jeff looks desperate. As he talks thoughtfully, he takes some jewelry from the handbag -- a couple of rings, diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls, etc. He discusses each piece, apparently trying to make some decision. Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. The first four of the songwriter's guests come through the door, admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter dashes off a loud vamp of greeting on the piano, then gets up to offer drinks. Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald but gives up any attempt at listening. He lifts the long-focus lens up to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: She appears to be attempting to deduce what to undertake or where to proceed, and she anxiously glances at a pair of men pedestrians. He swiftly elevates his telephoto camera to his eye, and we are now afforded a waist-high view as the focus is adjusted by Jeff. The silhouette is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. Receiving no response, she traverses the avenue and situates herself at a vacant table in front of the cafe, where she requests a beverage. She is abruptly obscured by a figure of a man who enters the scene from the left side. It is Thorwald, bearing a lightweight cardboard carton under his arm. The camera pans him over to the right until he is obscured behind the edifice. He is much closer to the lens because he is on this side of the avenue, and he is, therefore, somewhat out of focus. He lowers the lens, and we observe Jeff's eyes travel across the screen as he envisions Thorwald's progression. Then sharpening his gaze, he picks up the telephoto lens, and easing himself back cautiously, commences observing Thorwald. Thorwald advances up the corridor and stands unlocking his entryway. As he hesitates, we can discern the cardboard carton he is bearing has the name of a laundry on it. He enters the apartment and activates the living room lights. He advances to the bedroom, and the lights illuminate there. A quantity of suits and overcoats are lying in a systematic heap on the bed. He extracts the laundry from the carton and places it on the bed adjacent to the suits. Then he proceeds to the dresser, and instead of storing the laundry away, he continues to extract the items from the drawers--pajamas, shirts, socks, etc. He accumulates these on the bed. Jeff lowers the camera swiftly. He picks up the telephone and dials a numeral, still maintaining his eyes on Thorwald. The telephone buzzes on filter, then is picked up and answered by a woman. For an instant, Jeff appears desperate. As he converses thoughtfully, he extracts some jewelry from the handbag -- a pair of rings, diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls, etc. He deliberates each article, apparently striving to make some resolution. Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an endeavor to discern what Thorwald is articulating. The first four of the songwriter's invitees come through the door, admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter dashes off a loud vamp of salutation on the piano, then rises to offer refreshments. Jeff redirects his focus back to Thorwald but relinquishes any attempt at listening. He elevates the telephoto lens up to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: She seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go, and a couple of men passersby are nervously looked at by her. His long-focus camera is quickly raised to his eye by him, and a waist-high shot is now given to us as Jeff adjusts the focus. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. Getting no reaction, the street is crossed by her, and she seats herself at an empty table in front of the cafe, where a drink is ordered by her. A man suddenly blots her out by entering the picture from the left side. It is Thorwald, who carries a lightweight cardboard box under his arm. The camera pans him over to the right until the building loses him behind it. The lens is much nearer to him because he is on this side of the street, and therefore, he is slightly out of focus. The lens is lowered by him, and Jeff's eyes travel across the screen as Thorwald's progression is imagined by him. Then sharpening his look, the long-focus lens is picked up by him, and he cautiously eases himself back and begins watching Thorwald. Thorwald comes up the corridor and stands unlocking his door. As he hesitates, the cardboard box he is carrying can be seen to have the name of a laundry on it. The apartment is entered by him, and the living room lights are turned on. He proceeds to the bedroom, and the lights go on there. A number of suits and top coats lie in an orderly pile on the bed. The laundry is taken out of the box by him and put on the bed next to the suits. Then he goes to the dresser, and instead of putting the laundry away, the contents of the drawers--pajamas, shirts, socks, etc.--are taken out by him. These are piled on the bed by him. The camera is quickly lowered by Jeff. A phone number is dialed by him, still keeping his eyes on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on filter, then a woman picks it up and answers. For a moment, he looks desperate. As he talks thoughtfully, he takes some jewelry from the handbag—apparently trying to make some decision about a couple of rings, diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls, etc. His camera lens is lowered by Jeff, and his chair is edged forward by him in an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. The first four of the songwriter's guests are admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend as they come through the door. A loud vamp of greeting is dashed off by the songwriter on the piano, then he gets up to offer drinks. His attention is turned back to Thorwald by Jeff, but he gives up any attempt at listening. The long-focus lens is lifted up to his eyes again by him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: She seems unsure of what to do or where to go, nervously glancing at a couple of male passersby. He quickly raises his long-focus camera, adjusting the focus to reveal Miss Lonely Hearts. Receiving no reaction, she crosses the street and sits at an empty cafe table, ordering a drink. A man enters from the left, obscuring her; it's Thorwald with a lightweight cardboard box. The camera follows him right until he disappears behind a building, slightly out of focus due to proximity. Jeff's eyes track Thorwald's imagined path. Sharpening his gaze, Jeff picks up the lens and cautiously watches Thorwald, who unlocks his door. The box he carries is from a laundry. Inside, Thorwald turns on the lights, revealing suits and coats on the bed. He places the laundry next to them, then empties dresser drawers of pajamas, shirts, and socks onto the bed. Jeff quickly lowers the camera, dials a number, and watches Thorwald while a woman answers. Jeff looks desperate, thoughtfully handling jewelry—rings, a diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls—while making a decision. He edges his chair forward to hear Thorwald, but the songwriter's guests arrive, admitted by his girlfriend. The songwriter plays a loud greeting on the piano and offers drinks. Jeff refocuses on Thorwald, abandoning any attempt to listen, and lifts the lens to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: She seems unsure of her next move, nervously eyeing a couple of male passersby. He quickly raises his long-focus camera, adjusting the focus to reveal Miss Lonely Hearts. Receiving no response, she crosses the street to sit at an empty cafe table and orders a drink. A man, Thorwald, enters from the left, carrying a lightweight cardboard box. The camera follows him until he disappears behind a building, slightly out of focus due to his proximity. Jeff imagines Thorwald's path, then resumes watching him with the long-focus lens. Thorwald unlocks his door, revealing a laundry-labeled box. Inside, he turns on lights and places laundry next to suits on the bed, then empties dresser drawers onto it. Jeff quickly lowers the camera, dials a number, and watches Thorwald while a woman answers. Jeff looks desperate, handling jewelry and discussing each piece. He edges forward to hear Thorwald but is distracted by the songwriter's guests arriving. The songwriter greets them with a piano vamp and offers drinks. Jeff refocuses on Thorwald, abandoning any attempt to listen, and lifts the lens again.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: She appears to be in a state of uncertainty, seemingly trying to determine what her next move should be or where she ought to go. Her eyes dart nervously toward a couple of men who are passing by, as if seeking some kind of reassurance or guidance. Meanwhile, he swiftly raises his long-focus camera to his eye, and we are now presented with a waist-high shot as Jeff meticulously adjusts the focus. The figure in the frame is none other than Miss Lonely Hearts. Receiving no response or acknowledgment, she decides to cross the street and takes a seat at an unoccupied table situated in front of the cafe, where she proceeds to order a drink. Suddenly, her presence is obscured by the figure of a man who enters the scene from the left side of the frame. This man is Thorwald, and he is carrying a lightweight cardboard box tucked securely under his arm. The camera follows his movement, panning him over to the right until he disappears from view behind the building. Because he is on this side of the street, he is much closer to the lens, which results in him being slightly out of focus. Jeff lowers the lens, and we observe his eyes as they travel across the screen, imagining the path Thorwald is taking. Then, with a sharpened gaze, he picks up the long-focus lens once more and, easing himself back with caution, begins to watch Thorwald intently. Thorwald makes his way up the corridor and pauses to unlock his door. As he hesitates, we can clearly see that the cardboard box he is carrying bears the name of a laundry. Upon entering the apartment, he turns on the living room lights, illuminating the space. He then moves to the bedroom, where the lights are also switched on. A number of suits and top coats are neatly arranged in a pile on the bed. He removes the laundry from the box and places it on the bed next to the suits. Then, he approaches the dresser, and instead of putting the laundry away, he begins to remove the contents of the drawers—pajamas, shirts, socks, and other items. He piles these onto the bed as well. Jeff quickly lowers the camera. He picks up the phone and dials a number, all the while keeping his eyes fixed on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on filter before being picked up and answered by a woman. For a brief moment, Jeff appears desperate. As he speaks thoughtfully, he takes out some jewelry from the handbag—a couple of rings, a diamond wristwatch, a brooch, pearls, and so on. He seems to be discussing each piece, apparently trying to reach some kind of decision. Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an attempt to hear what Thorwald is saying. Meanwhile, the first four guests of the songwriter arrive, admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter enthusiastically plays a loud vamp of greeting on the piano, then rises to offer drinks to his guests. Jeff shifts his attention back to Thorwald but eventually abandons any effort to listen. He raises the long-focus lens to his eyes once again, resuming his watchful observation.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: She appears to be in a state of uncertainty, seemingly trying to determine what her next move should be or where she ought to go. Her eyes dart nervously toward a couple of men who are passing by, as if seeking some kind of reassurance or guidance in their presence. Meanwhile, he swiftly raises his long-focus camera to his eye, and we are now presented with a waist-high shot as Jeff meticulously adjusts the focus with delicate precision. The figure that fills the frame is none other than Miss Lonely Hearts herself. Receiving no response or acknowledgment from her surroundings, she ultimately decides to cross the street and takes a seat at an unoccupied table, which is conveniently situated in front of the cafe. Here, she proceeds to order herself a drink, perhaps to gather her thoughts. Suddenly, her presence is partially obscured by the figure of a man who strides into the scene from the left side of the frame. This man is Thorwald, and he is carrying a lightweight cardboard box that is securely tucked under his arm. The camera attentively follows his movement, panning him over to the right until he eventually disappears from view behind the building. Because he is positioned on this side of the street, he is much closer to the lens, which results in him being slightly out of focus in the shot. Jeff lowers the lens, and we keenly observe his eyes as they travel across the screen, vividly imagining the path Thorwald is likely taking. Then, with a sharpened gaze and renewed focus, he picks up the long-focus lens once more and, easing himself back with caution, begins to watch Thorwald with intense scrutiny. Thorwald makes his way up the corridor and pauses to unlock the door to his apartment. As he hesitates momentarily, we can clearly see that the cardboard box he is carrying bears the name of a laundry, indicating its contents. Upon entering the apartment, he turns on the living room lights, which immediately illuminate the space with a warm glow. He then moves to the bedroom, where the lights are also switched on. A number of suits and top coats are neatly arranged in a pile on the bed. He carefully removes the laundry from the box and places it on the bed next to the suits. Then, he approaches the dresser, and instead of putting the laundry away, he begins to remove the contents of the drawers—pajamas, shirts, socks, and other items. He piles these onto the bed as well. Jeff quickly lowers the camera. He picks up the phone and dials a number, all the while keeping his eyes fixed on Thorwald’s every move. The phone buzzes on filter before being picked up and answered by a woman. For a brief moment, Jeff appears desperate. As he speaks thoughtfully, he takes out some jewelry from the handbag—a couple of rings, a diamond wristwatch, a brooch, pearls, and so on. He seems to be discussing each piece, apparently trying to reach some kind of decision. Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an attempt to hear what Thorwald is saying. Meanwhile, the first four guests of the songwriter arrive, admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter enthusiastically plays a loud vamp of greeting on the piano, then rises to offer drinks to his guests, setting a convivial atmosphere. Jeff shifts his attention back to Thorwald but eventually abandons any effort to listen. He raises the long-focus lens to his eyes once again, resuming his watchful and vigilant observation.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: She appears to be in a state of indecision, trying to determine her next move or destination, and her eyes dart nervously towards a couple of men passing by. Observing this, he swiftly raises his long-focus camera to his eye, and we are presented with a waist-high shot as Jeff meticulously adjusts the focus. The figure in view is identified as Miss Lonely Hearts. Receiving no acknowledgment or reaction from her surroundings, she decides to cross the street with a sense of purpose and settles herself at an unoccupied table in front of the café, where she proceeds to order a drink. Suddenly, her presence is obscured by the entrance of a man from the left side of the frame. This man is Thorwald, who is carrying a lightweight cardboard box tucked under his arm. The camera follows his movement, panning to the right until he disappears from view behind the building. Due to his proximity to the lens, being on this side of the street, he appears slightly out of focus. Jeff lowers the lens momentarily, and his eyes trace Thorwald's imagined path across the screen. With a sharpened gaze, he picks up the long-focus lens once more and, easing himself back with caution, begins to observe Thorwald intently. Thorwald makes his way up the corridor and pauses to unlock his door. As he hesitates, the cardboard box he carries reveals the name of a laundry printed on it. He enters the apartment and switches on the living room lights, then moves to the bedroom, illuminating it as well. On the bed lies an orderly pile of suits and top coats. Thorwald removes the laundry from the box and places it on the bed beside the suits. He then approaches the dresser and, instead of storing the laundry, begins to empty the drawers, extracting pajamas, shirts, socks, and other items, which he adds to the growing pile on the bed. Jeff quickly lowers the camera and reaches for the phone, dialing a number while keeping his eyes fixed on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on filter before being answered by a woman, and for a brief moment, Jeff's expression turns desperate. As he speaks thoughtfully, he retrieves some jewelry from a handbag, examining a couple of rings, a diamond wristwatch, a brooch, pearls, and other pieces, seemingly deliberating over each one. Jeff lowers his camera lens and nudges his chair forward, straining to catch any words Thorwald might be saying. Meanwhile, the first four guests of the songwriter arrive, admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter greets them with a loud, cheerful vamp on the piano before rising to offer drinks. Jeff redirects his focus back to Thorwald but abandons any effort to eavesdrop. He raises the long-focus lens to his eyes once again, resuming his watchful observation.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: She appears indecisive and nervously glances at a couple of male passersby. Jeff quickly raises his long-focus camera, adjusting the focus to capture Miss Lonely Hearts as she crosses the street to sit at an empty cafe table and orders a drink. Suddenly, Thorwald enters the frame, carrying a lightweight cardboard box, and the camera follows him until he disappears behind a building. Jeff imagines Thorwald's path, then resumes watching him through the lens as Thorwald unlocks his door, revealing a laundry-labeled box. Inside, Thorwald turns on the lights, places the laundry next to a pile of suits on the bed, and empties dresser drawers onto it. Jeff quickly lowers the camera, dials a number, and, while speaking to a woman on the phone, examines jewelry from a handbag, seemingly making a decision. As the songwriter's guests arrive and are greeted with a piano vamp, Jeff refocuses on Thorwald, abandoning any attempt to listen, and raises the long-focus lens to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: She seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go, and she nervously looks at a couple of men passersby, who are chatting animatedly about a recent local sports event. He quickly raises his long-focus camera, a model favored by professional photographers for its precision, to his eye, and we are now given a waist-high shot as the focus is adjusted by Jeff, an experienced photographer known in his circle for capturing candid moments. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts, a nickname given by Jeff to a neighbor he observes, known for her solitary and melancholic demeanor. Getting no reaction, she crosses the street and seats herself at an empty table in front of the cafe, a quaint spot known for its artisanal coffee, where she orders a drink. She is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a man who enters the picture from the left side. It is Thorwald, a seemingly ordinary neighbor who has recently aroused suspicion, carrying a lightweight cardboard box under his arm. The camera pans him over to the right until he is lost behind the building, a red-brick structure typical of the neighborhood. He is much nearer the lens because he is on this side of the street, and he is, therefore, slightly out of focus. Jeff lowers the lens, and we see his eyes travel across the screen as he imagines Thorwald's progression, aware that his actions might unravel the mystery he's piecing together. Then sharpening his look, he picks up the long-focus lens, and easing himself back cautiously, begins watching Thorwald. Thorwald comes up the corridor typical of the apartment building styles of the 1950s and stands unlocking his door. As he hesitates, we can see the cardboard box he is carrying has the name of a laundry, a popular dry-cleaning service that offers home delivery, on it. He enters the apartment and turns on the living room lights. He proceeds to the bedroom, and the lights go on there. A number of suits and top coats, indicative of his meticulous nature, are lying in an orderly pile on the bed. He takes the laundry out of the box and puts it on the bed next to the suits. Then he goes to the dresser, and instead of putting the laundry away, he proceeds to take out the contents of the drawers--pajamas, shirts, socks, etc., as though preparing for an unexpected departure. He piles these on the bed. Jeff lowers the camera quickly. He picks up the phone and dials a number, still keeping his eyes on Thorwald, whose actions raise further suspicions. The phone buzzes on filter, then is picked up and answered by a woman, whose distinctive accent suggests she might be from another part of the country. For a moment, Jeff looks desperate. As he talks thoughtfully, he takes some jewelry from the handbag -- a couple of rings, diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls, etc., each piece potentially holding sentimental value or clues to a deeper story. He discusses each piece, apparently trying to make some decision. Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. The first four of the songwriter's guests come through the door, admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend, whose keen interest in local theater productions often garners lively discussions. The songwriter dashes off a loud vamp of greeting on the piano, then gets up to offer drinks, echoing the warm hospitality typical of gatherings in his home. Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald but gives up any attempt at listening. He lifts the long-focus lens up to his eyes again, determined to catch any detail that could unravel the enigma.

Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. A number of suits and top coats are lying in an orderly pile on the bed. He takes the laundry out of the box and puts it on the bed next to the suits. Then he goes to the dresser and instead of putting the laundry away he proceeds to take out the contents of the drawerspajamas shirts socks etc. He piles these on the bed. Jeff lowers the camera quickly. He picks up the phone and dials a number still keeping his eyes on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on filter then is picked up and answered by a woman. For a moment Jeff looks desperate. As he talks thoughtfully he takes some jewelry from the handbag  a couple of rings diamond wristwatch brooch pearls etc. He discusses each piece apparently trying to make some decision. Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. The first four of the songwriter's guests come through the door admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter dashes off a loud vamp of greeting on the piano then gets up to offer drinks. Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald but gives up any attempt at listening. He lifts the longfocus lens up to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: She seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go and she nervously looks at a couple of men passersby. He quickly raises his longfocus camera to his eye and we are now given a waisthigh shot as the focus is adjusted by Jeff. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. Getting no reaction she crosses the street and seats herself at an empty table in front of the cafe where she orders a drink. She is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a man who enters the picture from the left side. It is Thorwald carrying a lightweight cardboard box under his arm. The camera pans him over to the right until he is lost behind the building. For a moment Jeff looks desperate. As he talks thoughtfully he takes some jewelry from the handbag  a couple of rings diamond wristwatch brooch pearls etc. He discusses each piece apparently trying to make some decision. Jeff lowers his camera lens and edges his chair forward in an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. The first four of the songwriter's guests come through the door admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter dashes off a loud vamp of greeting on the piano then gets up to offer drinks. Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald but gives up any attempt at listening. He lifts the longfocus lens up to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: She seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go and she nervously looks at a couple of men passersby. He quickly raises his longfocus camera to his eye and we are now given a waisthigh shot as the focus is adjusted by Jeff. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. The songwriter dashes off a loud vamp of greeting on the piano then gets up to offer drinks. Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald but gives up any attempt at listening. He lifts the longfocus lens up to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The dog seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go, and the dog nervously looks at a couple of men passersby. The bird quickly raises its long-focus camera to its eye, and we are now given a waist-high shot as the focus is adjusted by a penguin. The figure is that of Mr. Curious. Getting no reaction, the dog crosses the street and seats itself at an empty table in front of the cafe, where the dog orders a drink. The dog is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a woman who enters the picture from the left side. It is a magician, carrying a lightweight cardboard box under her arm. The camera pans her over to the right until she is lost behind the building. She is much nearer the lens because she is on this side of the street, and she is, therefore, slightly out of focus. She lowers the lens, and we see the penguin's eyes travel across the screen as it imagines the magician's progression. Then sharpening its look, it picks up the long-focus lens, and easing itself back cautiously, begins watching the magician. The magician comes up the corridor and stands unlocking her door. As she hesitates, we can see the cardboard box she is carrying has the name of a bakery on it. She enters the apartment and turns on the living room lights. She proceeds to the bedroom, and the lights go on there. A number of dresses and hats are lying in an orderly pile on the bed. The magician takes the bakery items out of the box and puts them on the bed next to the dresses. Then she goes to the dresser, and instead of putting the bakery items away, she proceeds to take out the contents of the drawers--scarves, belts, gloves, etc. She piles these on the bed. The penguin lowers the camera quickly. It picks up the phone and dials a number, still keeping its eyes on the magician. The phone buzzes on filter, then is picked up and answered by a rabbit. For a moment, the penguin looks desperate. As it talks thoughtfully, it takes some jewelry from the handbag -- a couple of rings, diamond wristwatch, brooch, pearls, etc. It discusses each piece, apparently trying to make some decision. The penguin lowers its camera lens and edges its chair forward in an effort to hear what the magician is saying. The first four of the scientist's guests come through the door, admitted by the scientist's sibling. The scientist dashes off a loud vamp of greeting on the piano, then gets up to offer drinks. The penguin turns its attention back to the magician but gives up any attempt at listening. It lifts the long-focus lens up to its eyes again.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: She seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go, and she nervously looks at a couple of women passersby. He quickly raises his telescope to his eye, and we are now given a chest-high shot as the focus is adjusted by Jeff. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. Getting no reaction, she crosses the street and seats herself at an empty bench in front of the library, where she orders a pastry. She is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a woman who enters the picture from the left side. It is Thorwald, carrying a lightweight wicker basket under his arm. The camera pans him over to the right until he is lost behind the fountain. He is much nearer the lens because he is on this side of the park, and he is, therefore, slightly out of focus. He lowers the binoculars, and we see Jeff's eyes travel across the screen as he imagines Thorwald's progression. Then sharpening his look, he picks up the long-focus binoculars, and easing himself back cautiously, begins watching Thorwald. Thorwald comes up the staircase and stands unlocking his gate. As he hesitates, we can see the wicker basket he is carrying has the name of a bakery on it. He enters the cabin and turns on the kitchen lights. He proceeds to the study, and the lights go on there. A number of paintings and picture frames are lying in an orderly pile on the desk. He takes the bread out of the basket and puts it on the desk next to the paintings. Then he goes to the wardrobe, and instead of putting the bread away, he proceeds to take out the contents of the shelves—hats, scarves, belts, etc. He piles these on the desk. Jeff lowers the binoculars quickly. He picks up the phone and dials a number, still keeping his eyes on Thorwald. The phone buzzes on speaker, then is picked up and answered by a man. For a moment, Jeff looks desperate. As he talks thoughtfully, he takes some coins from the wallet—a couple of quarters, gold pocket watch, pendant, emeralds, etc. He discusses each piece, apparently trying to make some decision. Jeff lowers his binoculars and edges his chair forward in an effort to hear what Thorwald is saying. The first four of the artist's guests come through the door, admitted by the artist's assistant. The artist dashes off a loud note of greeting on the violin, then gets up to offer snacks. Jeff turns his attention back to Thorwald but gives up any attempt at listening. He lifts the long-focus binoculars up to his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She appears to be attempting to decide which book to read or which movie to watch, and she hesitantly scans a couple of men walking their dogs. He swiftly swings his long-focus camera from his eye, and we are now presented with a knee-high shot as the brightness is adjusted by Jeff. The figure is that of Miss Lonely Hearts. Receiving little interest, she heads down the street and reclines at an empty bench in front of the library, where she requests a book. She is suddenly obscured by a figure of a man who strolls into the frame from the left side. It is Thorwald, holding a lightweight puzzle box under his arm. The camera tracks him over to the right until he disappears behind the statue. He remains much nearer the lens because he is on this side of the street, and he is, therefore, slightly out of frame. He raises the lens, and we see Jeff's eyes dart across the screen as he envisions Thorwald's path. Then sharpening his glance, he grabs the long-focus lens, and reclining himself back cautiously, begins observing Thorwald. Thorwald moves up the walkway and stands examining his door. As he pauses, we can see the puzzle box he is holding has the name of a bookstore on it. He steps into the apartment and activates the hallway lights. He proceeds to the office, and the lights flicker on there. A number of novels and journals are lying in an orderly stack on the table. He extracts the puzzle from the box and places it on the table next to the novels. Then he approaches the bookshelf, and instead of placing the puzzle away, he begins to arrange the contents of the shelves--novels, magazines, photographs, etc. He stacks these on the table. Jeff raises the camera quickly. He grabs the phone and taps a number, still directing his eyes on Thorwald. The phone beeps on filter, then is picked up and responded to by a woman. For an instant, Jeff looks curious. As he speaks thoughtfully, he extracts some postcards from the handbag -- a couple of stamps, vintage wristwatch, bookmark, photographs, etc. He examines each item, apparently attempting to make some decision. Jeff raises his camera lens and adjusts his chair backward in an attempt to ignore what Thorwald is discussing. The first four of the songwriter's guests drift through the door, admitted by the songwriter's girlfriend. The songwriter plays a cheerful riff of greeting on the piano, then sits down to propose snacks. Jeff redirects his focus back to Thorwald but abandons any effort at watching. He lowers the long-focus lens from his eyes again.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The calendar seems to be trying to figure out what to do or where to go, and it nervously looks at a couple of lamps passersby. The painting quickly raises its long-focus telescope to its eye, and we are now given a waist-high shot as the focus is adjusted by Tina. The figure is that of Mr. Lonesome Hopes. Getting no reaction, the calendar crosses the street and seats itself at an empty chair in front of the bakery, where it orders a sandwich. The calendar is suddenly blotted out by a figure of a banana who enters the picture from the left side. It is Goldsmith, carrying a lightweight plastic bag under its arm. The telescope pans it over to the right until it is lost behind the tree. It is much nearer the lens because it is on this side of the street, and it is, therefore, slightly out of focus. The painting lowers the lens, and we see Tina's eyes travel across the screen as she imagines Goldsmith's progression. Then sharpening her look, she picks up the long-focus lens, and easing herself back cautiously, begins watching Goldsmith. Goldsmith comes up the hallway and stands unlocking its suitcase. As it hesitates, we can see the plastic bag it is carrying has the name of a bookstore on it. It enters the museum and turns on the kitchen lights. It proceeds to the attic, and the lights go on there. A number of hats and scarves are lying in an orderly pile on the rug. It takes the bookstore's goods out of the bag and puts them on the rug next to the hats. Then it goes to the shelf, and instead of putting the bookstore's goods away, it proceeds to take out the contents of the boxes--journals, maps, postcards, etc. It piles these on the rug. Tina lowers the telescope quickly. She picks up the clock and dials a number, still keeping her eyes on Goldsmith. The clock buzzes on speaker, then is picked up and answered by a giraffe. For a moment, Tina looks desperate. As she talks thoughtfully, she takes some marbles from the backpack--a couple of stones, sapphire bracelet, pin, rubies, etc. She discusses each piece, apparently trying to make some decision. Tina lowers her telescope lens and edges her seat forward in an effort to hear what Goldsmith is saying. The first four of the baker's customers come through the gate, admitted by the baker's cousin. The baker dashes off a loud chorus of greeting on the guitar, then gets up to offer candies. Tina turns her attention back to Goldsmith but gives up any attempt at listening. She lifts the long-focus lens up to her eyes again.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She seems to be attempting to decide what to wear or how to dance, and she anxiously glances at a duo of women bystanders. He hurriedly flips his wide-brim hat onto his head, and we are now presented with a close-up shot as the angle is altered by Sam. The figure is that of Miss Shadowy Dreams. Receiving no acknowledgement, she hops the fence and perches herself at an empty counter in front of the diner, where she requests a meal. She is suddenly obscured by a figure of a woman who enters the picture from the right side. It is Jenkins, lifting a bulky leather suitcase over her shoulder. The camera follows her over to the left until she vanishes behind the tree. She is much closer to the lens because she is on this side of the yard, and she is, therefore, slightly blurred. She raises the lens, and we observe Sam's mouth twitch across the frame as he imagines Jenkins' journey. Then sharpening his gaze, he grabs the wide-brim lens, and reclining himself forward cautiously, begins observing Jenkins. Jenkins arrives at the hallway and pauses unlocking her gate. As she lingers, we can see the leather suitcase she is lifting has the emblem of a bakery on it. She steps into the house and switches on the dining room lights. She moves to the office, and the lights flicker on there. Numerous dresses and hats are resting in a neat stack on the floor. She extracts the bakery goods out of the suitcase and sets them on the floor beside the dresses. Then she proceeds to the cabinet, and instead of storing the goods, she begins to remove the contents of the shelves—towels, gloves, scarves, etc. She stacks these on the floor. Sam drops the hat promptly. He grabs the radio and dials a station, still keeping his ears on Jenkins. The radio crackles on air, then is tuned in and answered by a man. For an instant, Sam looks hopeful. As he talks pensively, he retrieves some coins from the satchel—a couple of nickels, golden locket, badge, trinkets, etc. He examines each piece, apparently trying to make some choice. Sam raises his camera lens and slides his stool backward in an attempt to catch what Jenkins is speaking. The first four of the artist's companions step through the gate, greeted by the artist's partner. The artist bangs out a lively riff of welcome on the guitar, then stands up to offer snacks. Sam diverts his attention back to Jenkins but abandons any effort at hearing. He hoists the wide-brim lens up to his head again.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: She seems to be attempting to decipher where to sit or what to purchase, and she anxiously peers at a duo of women bystanders. He swiftly hoists his binoculars to his forehead, and we are now presented with a knee-high shot as the perspective is spun by Jeff. The silhouette is that of Miss Solitary Wanderer. Receiving no acknowledgment, she scuffles across the alley and perches herself at an unoccupied chair in front of the bookstore, where she requests a snack. She is suddenly obscured by a silhouette of a boy who enters the scene from the right side. It is Thorwald, clutching a hefty wooden crate under his elbow. The camera swivels him over to the left until he vanishes behind the tree. He is significantly closer to the frame because he is on this edge of the avenue, and he is, therefore, somewhat blurry. He drops the frame, and we notice Jeff's gaze drift across the panorama as he envisions Thorwald's passage. Then fine-tuning his vision, he grasps the long-focus frame and reclining backward cautiously, commences observing Thorwald. Thorwald approaches the hallway and stands fastening his gate. As he pauses, we can observe the wooden crate he is holding has the label of a bakery on it. He steps into the office and illuminates the dining room lamps. He advances to the studio, and the lamps flicker there. A collection of hats and scarves are scattered in a chaotic heap on the rug. He extracts the baked goods from the crate and places them on the rug next to the hats. Then he strides to the closet, and instead of arranging the baked goods, he proceeds to withdraw the contents of the cupboards—belts, ties, gloves, etc. He stacks these on the rug. Jeff drops the binoculars hastily. He reaches for the remote and tunes a channel, still focusing his gaze on Thorwald. The remote beeps on speaker, then is muted and acknowledged by a gentleman. For a fleeting instant, Jeff seems anxious. As he converses pensively, he fishes out some coins from the suitcase—a couple of quarters, silver bracelet, locket, beads, etc. He contemplates each piece, evidently attempting to make some choice. Jeff drops his binocular frame and nudges his desk forward in an attempt to glimpse what Thorwald is doing. The first four of the sculptor's visitors come through the gateway, admitted by the sculptor's companion. The sculptor strikes a loud chord of welcome on the harp, then rises to proffer sandwiches. Jeff redirects his focus to Thorwald but relinquishes any endeavor at eavesdropping. He raises the long-focus frame up to his brow once more.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat tries to determine how to jump or when to leap, and it cautiously observes a pair of women cyclists. The monkey swiftly lifts its short-form telescope to its ear, and we are now shown a knee-deep glimpse as the brightness is corrected by Danny. The shadow is that of Sir Boredom. Receiving no response, the cat climbs the ladder and lounges upon a crowded bench atop the library, where it requests a sandwich. It is abruptly overshadowed by a shadow of a woman who exits the painting from the right side. It is Blanche, lugging a hefty metal suitcase over her shoulder. The telescope scans her over to the left until she disappears behind the mountain. She is much further from the glass because she is across that river, and she is, therefore, sharply in view. She raises the glass, and we see Danny’s elbows dance around the curtain as he dreams of Blanche's meandering. Then squinting his focus, he puts down the short-form glass, and leaning himself forward boldly, begins sketching Blanche. Blanche leaps down the staircase and pauses locking her window. As she contemplates, we can observe the metal suitcase she is dragging has the logo of a bakery on it. She exits the mansion and switches off the porch lamps. She retreats to the attic, and the lamps go off there. Several paintings and soft blankets are hanging in a messy row on the floor. She drops the pastries out of the suitcase and places them on the floor next to the paintings. Then she walks to the wardrobe, and instead of tossing the pastries away, she begins to remove the lid from the jars--scarves, hats, gloves, etc. She arranges these on the floor. Danny raises the telescope slowly. He puts down the radio and punches a button, still directing his elbows at Blanche. The radio chatter on speaker, then is ignored and dismissed by a man. For a moment, Danny appears joyful. As he laughs loudly, he extracts some marbles from the suitcase -- a few dice, golden stopwatch, pin, stones, etc. He critiques each item, apparently attempting to find some resolution. Danny raises his telescope glass and slides his desk backward in an effort to see what Blanche is doing. The first four of the painter's visitors stomp through the gate, escorted by the painter's brother. The painter crashes out a soft waltz of farewell on the harp, then lies down to request sandwiches. Danny redirects his gaze back to Blanche but relinquishes any hope of watching. He drops the short-form glass down to his ears again.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The narrative follows Jeff, who observes suspicious activities through his camera. Miss Lonely Hearts appears indecisive and unnoticed by passersby, including Thorwald, who soon comes into focus carrying a cardboard box. Thorwald enters his apartment, revealing a laundry box, and oddly begins piling clothing and laundry on the bed. Suspicious, Jeff calls someone while watching Thorwald, handling jewelry pensively. Despite the interruption of a songwriter's guests, Jeff refocuses on Thorwald, attempting to overhear him but ultimately raising his camera lens again to continue his surveillance.
